H3.text: what was the ancient egyptians spoken language. Egyptian Arabic

A4.text: By the time of classical antiquity, the spoken language had evolved into Demotic: its formation and development as a separate language from the Old Egyptian was strongly influenced by Aramaic and Ancient Greek.

A5.text: These were eventually supplanted by Arabic after the Muslim conquest of Egypt, although Bohairic Coptic remains in use as the liturgical language of the Coptic Church.

A6.text: Thesaurus Linguae Aegyptiae: Dictionary of the Egyptian language

A7.text: Ancient Egyptian in the wiki Glossing Ancient Languages (recommendations for the Interlinear Morphemic Glossing of Ancient Egyptian texts)

A8.text: The Egyptian language, or Ancient Egyptian, is an extinct branch of the Afro-Asiatic language family that was spoken in ancient Egypt.

A9.text: The Egyptian language is conventionally grouped into six major chronological divisions:

A10.text: Demotic is the name of the script derived from the hieratic beginning in the 7th century BC.

A11.text: Its classical form, known as 'Middle Egyptian,' served as the vernacular of the Middle Kingdom of Egypt and remained the literary language of Egypt until the Roman period.

A12.text: The Coptic alphabet was derived from the Greek alphabet, with adaptations for Egyptian phonology.

A13.text: By the Roman and Byzantine eras, the language later further diversified into various Coptic dialects written in the Greek alphabet.

A14.text: Egyptian is one of the earliest known written languages, first recorded in the hieroglyphic script in the late 4th millennium BC.

A15.text: It is also the longest-attested human language, with a written record spanning over 4,000 years.

A16.text: Chicago Demotic Dictionary is a dictionary of Demotic.

A17.text: Demotische Grammatik by Wilhelm Spiegelberg is a grammar of Demotic.
